ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This was a small seminar that met on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned elementary French, including conjugations of common verbs, common phrases, nouns, pronouns, and basic grammar.

It was incredible how much French I gained over the course of just one semester. Without having any foundation in the language, I feel much more confident about my ability to gain further language skills.
I developed the ability to read, write and understand French.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths of this course is that there were always many different ways to learn the language -- we used videos, a textbook, a workbook, additional exercises, and speaking in class. Weaknesses are that you have to do a lot of work to keep up in this class as it moves quickly and there is a lot of material.

Professor Ngame was one of the best language professors I have ever had. He is very patient and deliberate in his teaching. I think the powerpoints and written guides could have been a bit more organized at times to help students study and review.
This course made it very easy to pick up conversational French especially, as the professor made a point of speaking to the class almost entirely in French to strengthen our understanding.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The French in Action part of this class worked well online as it involves watching videos and practicing by yourself. However, the class itself was a bit difficult over Zoom. Pronunciation was definitely difficult to work out with only microphones and speakers.
The small class size for our Zoom section was very beneficial to our French studies.
The structure of the course itself was well-suited to distance learning, although obviously conversation flows less freely through a screen.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are interested in learning French and interested in the French culture. It is a bit of work though, so you need to be motivated and prepared for that.
I would recommend this course to any student wanting to learn French in a conversational and involved manner.
